awd_titl_txt: Preparing Engineering Students for Three Gateway Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Alabama (UA) Tuscaloosa project titled "Preparing Engineering Students for Three Gateway Courses" leverages S-STEM scholarships to increase the number of graduates in selected engineering disciplines using an approach referred to as Learning in Advance (LIA). In the LIA approach, special preparatory courses are offered for selected courses (gateway courses) identified as key attrition points in engineering programs. Each preparatory course is taken the semester before the corresponding gateway course. A subset of the students who successfully complete the preparatory course will be selected to receive a scholarship based on academic potential and demonstrated financial need.

The gateway courses identified at the institution include: Circuit Analysis, Data Structures /Algorithms and Statics. LIA introduces key concepts targeting common misconceptions before they become impediments to learning. The LIA program embodies three principles: (1) partnership with students after their freshman year; (2) preparation of students for critical gateway courses prior to their enrollment in those courses; and (3) mentoring of students during those critical courses and beyond. The intellectual merit of the project lies in the development and implementation of three preparatory courses to improve student retention in an array of STEM fields: Electrical, Computer, Aerospace, Civil, Construction, and Mechanical Engineering as well as Computer Science. The potential broader impacts of the project include increasing the number of graduates in targeted majors by a total of 35 per year and providing scholarships to 40 diverse students who demonstrate academic talent and financial need. A social science study set within the framework of the theory of embeddedness will be implemented in order to investigate the factors linking program components and student persistence in engineering.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to increase the number of engineering graduates in selected disciplines (e.g. Electrical and Computer Engineering; Computer Science; Civil, Construction, Environmental Engineering; Mechanical Engineering; and Aerospace Engineering and Mechanics) at the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa.  In support of this goal we launched a Learning in Advance (LIA) program that provided 10-week one-credit-hour courses to directly prepare students for gateway courses (which historically have high failure rates) in each discipline.  These gateway courses were Circuit Analysis, Statics, and Data Structures & Algorithms.  After completing an LIA course, scholarships were granted based on student financial need and scholarship awardees were inducted as LIA scholars participating in professional development activities and receiving faculty mentoring while working towards their degree completion.

Over the program duration, 185 students enrolled in the LIA prep courses and 91 students received scholarships.  Among students awarded scholarships, nearly half (45%) were from groups underrepresented in engineering (females and/or designated minority groups). Students in the LIA program have been very successful in completing the gateway course and continuing in their major. Their success rate as a group is higher than the overall success rates in these courses; and in their responses to open-ended survey questions, LIA students often attribute some of their success to the LIA prep course or to the faculty mentors.  After the Spring 2024 semester, 63 of 91 students who received scholarship support had graduated with an undergraduate STEM degree.  Further, an additional 54 students who completed the prep class (but were not awarded scholarships) have also graduated with an undergraduate STEM degree.

Overall, the program at the University of Alabama has been a very positive experience for the students who participated in it. Across all the years of the program students who enrolled in LIA courses gave high ratings to the course and the instructors, and they felt it was very helpful in preparing them for the targeted gateway course. In addition to receiving an introduction to critical concepts, they especially liked the small classes, pace of the course, and close attention of a faculty member. Those who received scholarships following the prep course were very grateful for this additional resource, often mentioning that it allowed them to worry less about money and to spend more time on academic work, because they could quit a part-time job or reduce the number of hours they had to work at a job. The LIA Scholars were also appreciative of the faculty mentors they had throughout their remaining years at the university. Furthermore, the program was very successful in reaching students from groups typically underrepresented in engineering.
